required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Influence of Different Anesthetic Procedures on Sleep Disorder Breathing
clinical_study.official_title: Influence of Different Anesthetic Procedures on Sleep Disorder Breathing in Adult Patients Undergoing Elective Surgery

lead_sponsor.agency: St. Anne's University Hospital Brno, Czech Republic

clinical_study.source: St. Anne's University Hospital Brno, Czech Republic

brief_summary.textblock: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common form of sleep disordered breathing characterized by partial or complete upper airway obstructions during sleep. OSA is associated with major comorbidities and perioperative complications. These complications are caused not only by the OSA itself, but also by exacerbations of this syndrome during the perioperative period (1). Benzodiazepines, volatile anesthetics and opioids may lead to lower hypoxia and hypercapnia sensitivity and may cause respiratory depression (2-5). Therefore, preference of neuraxial blockades and avoidance of opioids has been suggested for patients with OSA (6). However, there is still lack of evidence to evaluate the effects of various anesthesia procedures on OSA (6,7). We hypothesize different anesthetic procedures will have different effect on OSA exacerbations in the postoperative period. Accordingly, the aim of this study is to compare the number of sleep disordered breathing episodes in the postoperative period in patients with different anesthetic procedures.

primary_outcome.description: Changes (post-pre) in apnea-hypopnea index 4 nights post surgery

arm_group.description: orthopedic surgery plus epidural anesthesia (without opioids use)
orthopedic surgery plus subarachnoid anesthesia (plus intrathecal opioid)
orthopedic surgery plus regional anesthesia (peripheral nerve block, continous or single shot, without opioid use)

study_pop.textblock: consecutive patients undergoing elective orthopedic surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- elective orthopedic surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- already diagnosed sleep disorder breathing
- continuous positive airway pressure therapy
- tracheostomy
- American Society of Anesthesiologists class IV-V
